conclusion: Understanding the problem of a square conductor frame moving through a magnetic field to find the duration of induced current.
Square conductor frame with side length \( l \) moves uniformly with speed \( v \) through a magnetic field of width \( d \), represented by crosses indicating direction into the page.
Magnetic field is perpendicular to the motion, important for inducing emf.
Induced current occurs with a change in magnetic flux through the frame.
Frame moves to the right with speed \( v \), magnetic field is between two vertical dashed lines, distance \( d \) apart.
As the frame enters the magnetic field, one side cuts the magnetic field lines, inducing an emf and current.
Induced current starts when the first side enters the field and stops when the last side exits.
When the frame is fully inside the field, there's no change in flux, so no induced current.
Time with induced current is the time to enter plus the time to exit the field.
Time to enter the field is \( t_{\text{enter}} = \frac{l}{v} \).
Time to exit the field is \( t_{\text{exit}} = \frac{l}{v} \).
Total time with induced current is \( t_{\text{total}} = \frac{2l}{v} \).
Induced current occurs only when the frame is partially inside the field, either entering or exiting.
Induced emf is proportional to the rate of change of magnetic flux, \( \phi = B \cdot A \).
As the frame enters, area \( A \) increases, causing \( \phi \) to increase, inducing emf and current.
When fully inside the field, \( A \) is constant, so no change in flux, no induced current.
As it exits, \( A \) decreases, causing another change in flux, inducing another current.
